'''Jan Piekałkiewicz''' (19 September 1892 – 19 February 1943) was a [[Poles|Polish]] [[economist]] and [[statistician]], [[politician]] and the [[Polish Underground State]]'s [[List of Government Delegates for Poland|Government Delegate]].

==Biography==
He was born on the 19 September 1892 in [[Kursk]], to a Polish [[intelligentsia]] family. He studied in [[St. Petersburg]] and in [[Poznań]].<ref name=WIEM>{{pl icon}} [http://portalwiedzy.onet.pl/46959,,,,piekalkiewicz_jan,haslo.html Piekałkiewicz Jan], [[WIEM Encyklopedia]]. Retrieved on 28 May 2009.</ref>

He was an employee of the [[Central Statistical Office (Poland)|Central Statistical Office]], and was one of the organizers of the [[Polish census of 1921]].<ref name=Interia>{{pl icon}} [http://encyklopedia.interia.pl/haslo?hid=94777 PIEKAŁKIEWICZ  Jan (1892-1943)], [[Encyklopedia Interia]]. Retrieved on 28 May 2009.</ref> From 1923 to 1924 he was a professor at the [[University of Lwów]].<ref name=WIEM/> From 1924 to 1939 he lectured in the Main Political School in Warsaw, and published over 50 works on finances, economics (in particular, [[econometrics]]) and statistics.<ref name=Interia/> He was a member of the [[Polish Statistical Society]],<ref>{{pl icon}} [http://www.stat.gov.pl/gus/5840_4342_PLK_HTML.htm POLSKIE TOWARZYSTWO STATYSTYCZNE], Główny Urząd Statystyczny. Retrieved on 28 May 2009.</ref> and on 1927 he became a member of the [[International Statistical Institute]].<ref name=WIEM/> He worked with the Statistical Commission of the [[League of Nations]].<ref name=WIEM/> He was considered a leading Polish expert on economical statistics.<ref name=WIEM/>

He was a member of the [[Polish People's Party "Piast"]] (''PSL "Piast"'', from 1926) and [[People's Party (Poland)|People's Party]] (''Stronnictwo Ludowe'', from 1931). From 1938 to 1939 he was a member of the Main Council of the People's Party.<ref name=WIEM/> Following the [[German invasion of Poland]], from 1940 he was a member of the underground arm of the People's Party, the [[People's Party "Roch"]] (''Stronnictwo Ludowe "Roch"'').<ref name=WIEM/> In December 1940 he became Deputy to the [[Polish Underground State]]'s [[List of Government Delegates for Poland|Government Delegate]] and on 2 August<ref>{{pl icon}} [http://www.ih.ap.siedlce.pl/ Brief review of Gmitruk "Jan Piekałkiewicz bohater zapomniany”] on the page of Akademia Podlaska. Retrieved on 28 May 2009.</ref> (or 17 September<ref name=ak>Grzegorz Ostasz [http://www.polishresistance-ak.org/17%20Article.htm  The Polish Government-in-Exile's Home Delegature], 30 September 2003. Retrieved on 28 May 2009.</ref> - sources vary) 1942 he replaced [[Cyryl Ratajski]] as Delegate.<ref name=WIEM/><ref name=ak/>

As Delegate, he confirmed the creation of the Council to Aid Jews [[Żegota]] and extension of full aid to Polish political prisoners. He also ordered the full documentation of the [[Nazi crimes against ethnic Poles]] and [[The Holocaust in Poland|the Jews]]. He informed the [[Western Allies]] about the [[Holocaust]].<ref name=WIEM/> He supported the studies on the creation of the post-war Polish-German border on [[Lusatian Neisse]] and [[Oder]].<ref name=WIEM/> In his speeches to the nation, published in [[Biuletyn Informacyjny]], he called up everyone to join in the civil struggles and warned collaborators that they faced the death penalty for betraying the Polish nation. He also wanted to establish cooperation between the [[Polish Underground State]], loyal to the [[Polish government in exile]] in [[London]], and the communist [[Polish Workers Party]] (PPR).<ref>Jan M. Ciechanowski, ''The Warsaw Rising of 1944'', Cambridge University Press, 2002, ISBN 0-521-89441-7, [http://books.google.com/books?id=2kvvMiclgVMC&pg=PA92&vq=Piekalkiewicz&dq=%22Jan%2BPieka%C5%82kiewicz%22&source=gbs_search_s&cad=0 Google Print, p.92]</ref> As Delegate, he was succeeded by [[Jan Stanisław Jankowski]].

He was arrested by the Germans on 19 February 1943, tortured, then murdered on 19 June 1943.<ref name=WIEM/><ref name=ak/><ref>Paweł Dubiel, Józef Kozak: Polacy w II wojnie światowej: kim byli, co robili. Warszawa: Oficyna Wydawnicza RYTM, 2003, p. 123. ISBN 83-7399-054-2.</ref>

In 1995 he was posthumously awarded the [[Order of the White Eagle (Poland)|Order of the White Eagle]].

*O programie gospodarczym Polski, with [[Brunon Balukiewicz]]
*La Pologne contemporaine : atlas statistique, 1926
*Bilans płatniczy polski = La Balance des payements de la Pologne, 1926
*Okrȩgi gospodarcze Polski : Les régions économiques de la Pologne, 1927
*Długi samorządu terytorjalnego = Les dettes des administrations autonomes territoriales, 1929
*Le service statistique des banques de crédit agricole hypothécaire, 1931
*La statistique de l'activité économique des entreprises d'état, 1933
*Statistique du crédit hypothécaire, 1933
*Sprawozdanie z badań skladu ludności robotniczej w Polsce metoda̜ reprezentacyjna̜, 1934
